item.title: Deconvolution and the System Matrix
item.description: Delving into the practicalities of the inverse problem of reconstructing Compton camera images will lead you to Legandre polynomials or Maximum Likelihood methods, most likely. Since last week I have been interested in both the analytical reconstruction techniques as well as some of the iterative methods. Regarding iterative methods, what I found is that it is difficult to get a feeling on how the iterative methods properly work simply because the algorithms (I write mine in Python) is incredibly slow.

item.title: Cone-Surface Projections
item.description: One of the first properties encountered in Compton camera image reconstruction is the cone-surface projection. Understandig the properties of this geometrical object will set the ground works for understanding more advanced models. I was reading some articles of the early versions of the Compton camera image reconstruction procedure when I came across Ref.[1] talking about the cone-surface projections. They investigated a primitive version of a ‘‘Compton camera’’. Well, it kind of had some properties like a Compton camera like a scatterer and an absorber but they assumed that photons only scatter at a fixed given angle.
